ok you're gonna hafta refill the wish list now, somehow there's only two things left

and you help me hang on, just by existing and sharing when you are able. then i in turn use that to support me as i support others and so on and so forth. putting your body at risk by being at a protest isn't the only way to fight fascism. you're fighting it all the time already.

and i bet every single one of us provide something of value to the effort just by existing. you are there for others so much you probably have no idea how much you're helping. and me, even if i didn't internet, i support my abled partner who can contribute more because of me.

it's not even about our "feelings", it's about what we can reasonably contribute in the middle of a time when we are also one of the groups of people under attack by policy. the stress and financial cost of just trying to get basic living supplies is enough to wipe us out!

likewise. surviving this is, as i have heard several people say, a revolutionary act all by itself. this is not easy stuff for people like us to survive. if we can keep ourselves alive through it and recover from it, we may have the resources to pick up where we left off.

(i'm reminded by a reply that i might have an outdated pov, because everyone i grew up with, if they were lucky enough to purchase a single family home on its own land, they lived there forever, like they had married the house. no "investment" houses ever, just lived-in homes.)

it really is the biggest of yikes. i've been in that neighborhood a few times (it's exactly as gated as it sounds like it would be) for work and, like, there's a mansion made of bricks from old palaces and shit. guillotine level yikes.

i can't even wrap my mind around that. i know that these people exist but when i was growing up every single person i knew, if they were lucky enough to own a single family house on its own land, they lived there forever. like they married the house!
yup, i had one in a (very exclusive, rich) neighborhood spitting distance from me that only very recently removed racist bullshit from their agreements.
yeah, good reminder, that's their actual literal original reason for being. people pretend that's not it now but it's still definitely it now.

100%, hoas are the devil. they belong in hell. they try to act like they're necessary for the community-owned property but they never stop there. and again, they must be full of people who just love to pay more taxes! i can't even.

people griping about this or that in their neighborhood "dragging down" property values honestly baffle the fuck out of me. are they all expecting to move soon? do they love high property taxes? what's the deal? or is it really actually 100% racist dog whistle? cause ... c'mon.

ok i have got to finally wonder out loud: do suburban people not understand that "high property value" is pretty much only in their favor when they are selling (leaving!) that property? the rest of the time, it just increases the tax burden if that area collects property taxes?
mostly i've only ever heard humblebee, these are full on ridiculous
oh my god she's essentially saying "your existence as a human being in your human being body is not helping your career" what the what what what

yes! making a point to try to give them whatever you can within your means to make helping you a positive experience for them means not just making them happy but also making it more likely they'll be willing to do it again if you're in need! i can't believe some people's nerve.

if you must ask others for free labor, make it explicitly safe & easy for them to say no! acknowledge that you're asking for something valuable in return for nothing. acknowledge that they may have other priorities and give them an easy way to say no. don't be a jerk about it.
you can! you can definitely do it! no free labor today!

maggie's favorite comedian is  (she really likes his trúmp impression actually, she cackles with laughter the whole time) and niko's favorite youtube is mighty car mods and he will run over to settle down and fluff up with happiness. they do not care for lucifer.

also they both understand that tv isn't real. at first maggie didn't, and would fly to the tv and look behind it, but she figured it out. they have preferences too. they liked the avengers movies, which was unexpected. and they don't want to re-watch stuff they've already seen.

they both react to the tv shows i watch, niko nods along when people explain and maggie will laugh at funny bits even if i don't laugh and there's no laugh track. none of that for the tv show that's not in english. maggie got interested when she heard a cat, but that's it.

oh interesting discovery i don't think i mentioned; i've had definite confirmation that when my birds watch tv with me, they are paying attention to what's being said. i've been watching a chinese drama and they can't read the subtitles so they're like and won't watch it.

but when you find yourself scared and alone and all of a sudden you don't know what the heck to do, it will save your life. so even if you get only a tiny bit done at a time, that's fine. work on it bit by bit as you can. it's totally worth it. ok i think i'm finally done.

lastly, keep it updated. this is hard. mine is out of date, actually. a lot has changed. i should probably go through and do it all over again, tbh. that is valuable, to make sure everything in my plan still works for me. it's a hard document to write. it takes a lot of time!

if you don't discuss it in advance, you may end up giving up too much of your autonomy and this fear may keep you from enacting your crisis plan. for instance, if you're afraid someone will try to take your pills away forever, agree to a timed lock box or to keep a certain .

stuff like allowing them to temporarily remove some of the means of harming yourself, without limiting your ability to get through your day or making you dependent on them. or agreeing to check-ins with them for a certain period of time. you should discuss this *in advance*.

because at some point you are going to want them all to buzz off. they aren't going to want to buzz off until they feel like it's safe to do so. consider being willing to place some restrictions on yourself to give them the confidence to leave you alone.

that's pretty much the basics, though the website i linked to has other important stuff. including how people should know when your crisis is over. that's a tough one, tbh, but you don't want to create a situation where people don't know when to leave you the fuck alone again.

it's also helpful here to include information for health providers like existing health conditions, allergies, current medications, even insurance info if you have it. basically anything someone would need to fill out for you on a form, in case you can't answer yourself.

a lot of trauma can be inflicted on people in crisis by really well meaning people who genuinely care but don't know what to do - so they fall back on popular messaging that is actually really harmful and dangerous. write down any "absolutely not"s so this doesn't happen.

the website document mentions this, but you also need be to explicit about which healthcare providers and treatments you're ok with and which you are not. absolutely zero percent of you are going to remember all of that shit. write it down. this part is vitally important.

give explicit instructions for others to follow here. while you should talk with your on-call people as you make this plan to get their consent and cooperation, you can't expect them to remember what you do and don't want in the moment - they may be scared too. write it down.

don't forget to write down their contact info even if you normally remember it - you might not be able to remember, or you might not be able to communicate with someone to tell them to contact someone else for you. be able to just point at the paper: "call jenny: 867-5309".

use that crisis plan outline pdf from here - that stuff includes the questions like...who do you want with you and who don't you want with you? how do you want them with you? what is their role here? what can they do for you that you can't do for yourself?

your crisis plan isn't meant to solve your problems. your crisis plan is meant to drag you through the crisis, kicking and screaming (or in my case, whimpering and playing ragdoll), until you're on the other side and out of immediate danger.

this is honestly right here - the idea that every minute you're focusing on this is a minute you're not harming yourself - the whole ball of wax. we're forcefully marching ourselves through this crisis second by second. we just need to make it to the other side.

after you get through what i call the crisis plan preamble, you can put every other coping strategy you have ever felt useful to you, just dump them all in there. every minute you're spending doing any of that stuff is a minute you're not harming yourself. every minute counts.

but regardless of the garbage mixed in with the helpful stuff, you will probably find a couple of strategies that feel right to you. it's all about trying to get your parasympathetic nervous system to wake up and help you out with the rest of the stuff on your crisis plan.

if you need a place to start to get ideas, search for 'self regulation strategies' and feel free to privately mock any of the overly positive (toxic positivity) bullshit you may find. (keep in mind one person's trash is another's treasure so be cautious about *publicly* mocking.)

but you start with something you know will give you time to orient yourself. you know what that is - and if you don't, now is the time to learn. anything that will give you a few minutes to just put the brakes on, stop running from the tiger, give your nervous system a time-out.

the stuff that you put there, that's between you and yourself. it could be stuff that doesn't involve anyone but you, or it may involve reaching out to others. it could be as simple as "sit down and listen to this music/watch this tv show/put a heating pad on your face."

the very first sheet should be basically a letter to yourself. loosely put: 'sup, self, i know things are shitty. if you're reading this, you're already on the right track and i'm proud of you. here's some of the things i want you to do *right this very second*.'

don't put any obstacles between you and your crisis plan. i understand wanting it to not be something a random person stumbles onto, of course, so like in an envelope is fine but no burying that envelope under anything to hide it. if it is at all inconvenient, it's not helpful.

you may not want to recall past moments of crisis, but if you can, try to think of a place you know for sure you'll be able to easily reach your plan. not in your fire safe, not in a filing cabinet behind the laundry baskets, not in a folder-in a folder-in a folder on your pc.

so even if you are normally able to very easily recall helpful self care stuff, you're not going to have the same recall when your nervous system thinks you're being chased by a tiger. use your "good" moments to put this stuff where you can get at it easily in case of tiger.

the thing about being in crisis is that your focus narrows way down. this is actually part of our body's self defense mechanisms, not any kind of failure on our part. this is intended to allow you to give the current danger your undivided attention, but it doesn't help much here.

if you have ever suddenly had a moment of clarity and said, "why didn't i think of that sooner, it seems so obvious now?!" write that down. don't let that thought slip into the ether believing you will remember it when you need it most. you won't remember it. write it down.

in my opinion, every crisis plan should start by being your past stable self guiding your future in-crisis self. you know yourself best, you know what helps you most but is so easy to forget in the moment. before we involve other people, get your past self on the case.

this is an article that has a basic crisis plan worksheet. everyone's crisis is different and this article seems to be more weighted towards mental health crises, but it's still a good place to start, so have a peek: https://mentalhealthrecovery.com/info-center/crisis-plan/

and of course i also constantly challenge the "you get sick and then you either die or recover" narrative, just by existing for so long as sick as i am. my full time job threatens the fuck out of a lot of unconsciously held myths that provide a feeling of comfort and security.

the better they know me, the more scary it is because they can't write off that fear by using the moralizing of health. they know i was already "a good person" who tried to do everything right, so i'm a constant challenge to that small comfort of control many people cherish.

which also touches on the discomfort that my very existence and daily life creates for them because it strips a layer of the veneer of false sense of security that it could not happen to them. it happened to me, it is happening to me. it could happen to them, too! scary! avoid!

to be honest, i understand why (sometimes it's because it hurts to hear how bad my "normal" is, or they feel helpless etc). i'm very used to my personal hellscape, but they aren't. what's not a big deal to me is horrifying to them. my regular life is stuff of their nightmares.

and one of the ways we can try to change overall attitudes is language, which has an inextricable feedback loop relationship with culture. we believe it because we say it and we say it because we believe it. so it's not about "you said a bad word so you're bad" for me, ykwim?

so, like, dividing people up based on "intelligence", using insults rooted in the concept, etc, ends up fucking over the already marginalized. for example iq tests, ridiculously racist. shit like that. so essentially just trying to end the normalization of demonizing "low int".

confidential to "jd" (i assume you deleted to avoid @'ing): anything that refers to cognitive ability. i call them "intelligence based" slurs. i personally believe the concept of "intelligence" itself is part of the problem, since it's flawed and usually used for evil, tbh.

if i point out that your *language* is ableist or racist, i'm talking about the language, i'm talking about the words. i'm not talking about the person. there are plenty of people who are genuinely trying very hard, but slip up. it's a process. it takes time. i'm one of them.

i should have clued in immediately when they pulled out the dictionary to insist an insult isn't a slur. but when i used the dictionary to define "slur" they pivoted to arguing it's not an *ableist" slur. i could have quit then, too. i'll learn my lesson someday.

nevermind, i blocked them. at first i thought they legit did not understand my explanation that intelligence-based insults are inherently ableist because i was too sleepy to make words, but they use squirrely argument tactics to maintain their grip on their rightness.

you've demonstrated an unwillingness to learn from someone giving you new information just because you don't like it. you just don't like what i'm saying so you reject it. you would rather double down than learn. so i'm done with your disingenuous "be humble enough to learn" bit.
this all started with this tweet [cn ableist slur]: https://twitter.com/lissajstrange/status/1284486821817319425?s=19
"that bullshit"
i wasn't saying it was about heritability. not all disabilities are inherited. this was not about heritability.

racial minorities and disabled people are both marginalized and oppressed groups that frequently have to fight stigmatizing language. do you not understand what i was getting at by asking if you are quicker to accept information from someone from another marginalized community?

[cn ableist slur] listen, i'm very tired this morning, does anyone else want to explain *why* the word "stupid" is an ableist slur to the person who just keeps telling me my explanation isn't good enough?

do you also simply argue "nuh uh" when you're told that a word is a racial slur, or do you accept learning from a member of that community? intelligence is, *absolutely*, considered an inherent quality of a person and has been used to classify whole racial groups as less than.

it's used specifically to abuse and oppress (both on an individual and institution level) people with cognitive disabilities. i did say this before. "stupid" is used in the context of a state of being, not a choice one makes. it's based on assumptions of lack of "intelligence".
*spoken to (autocorrect has been very insistent on replacing that with "spelled" for some reason)

using a dictionary entry to insist a word isn't a slur is a common method people use to refuse to learn from others in a community who is asking to be spelled to & treated with dignity. but if you insist it's the final word: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/slur definition 1, both a and b.

sup, just checking in to confirm that a lot of us consider "stupid" to be an ableist slur, used to abuse and oppress those with cognitive impairments, and if you want you say that you think someone is being willfully ignorant you can just say that.

there's more stuff i wanted to add but i just got to a wall of brain fog so i'm gonna rest and let other folks tag in with their awesome resources and suggestions for community and stuff. in fact,  is already on it with great stuff, you should follow them too.
if you've never seen it before, 's film unrest may be helpful to you. you can find different sources to watch it here:

for more information on mcas you can start with https://www.mastattack.org/ - in the upper right corner is a menu where you can choose the getting started stuff. this site is dense with info so take it slowly, but tons of resources here. any questions you have though, we can help.

, there's a great hashtag you can use for venting or chatting about your symptoms - it's intended as a no-unsolicited-advice place, so you won't get unprompted help but you will get people who 'get it' listening and supporting. it's neisvoid - no end in sight void.

hi chronicillness and disability twitter!  is one of the longcovid folks who has symptoms of mcas and has fatigue, among other things. they're new and need community and folks to chat with to help this make more sense. come say hi here.

myalgic encephalomyelitis has not had very much support from the medical community, but pwme try to make up for it by supporting one another with information and treatment options. many of us have been living with this for decades. you can always reach out.

please stop working out until you know for sure that you do or don't have myalgic encephalomyelitis. the primary characteristic of that condition is "post exertional malaise" and it will only make you worse the more you push against it. it's very real damage.

i hope you're not misunderstanding the way i'm *not* using "tribe". i haven't literally stricken it from my lexicon like tearing a page from a dictionary. native american tribes are still tribes, or nations, whichever they prefer. i just don't use it for my own purposes.

that's literal usage though, not the contested usage. when you refer to those tribes, you're not being metaphorical at all! i haven't seen anyone object to that. :) it's mainly using "my tribe" to refer to a community. (or using it in business or commercially to refer to a group)

i think i misspoke or misunderstood that last bit. if a native american wants to use "tribe" positively, that's who i meant when i said "sure fine". (i mean, it's theirs to use) the objection is to other people using it metaphorically as a synonym for "community".

for me, i usually *like* to understand, it helps, but sometimes i have to accept that maybe i won't be able to because i lack the experiences and perspectives they have. i don't have to understand the mechanism of harm to agree to stop causing it. it helps, though, yes.

then i say that's cool, i'm glad. but that doesn't negate the harm to other people. again, my math is: if my not doing a thing doesn't hurt anyone, but does prevent harm to others, even a minority of others, then i don't do the thing. even if others think i'm foolish for it.
they can go ahead. it doesn't affect me.

but it's an interesting point - if i say, "as a disabled person, ableist language is harmful" and yet a lot of other disabled people don't agree, is my claim - to that group or to that harm - less valid?

that's case-specific. in this case, it was pretty plain to me that the argument - that american people have long used "tribe/al/ist" negatively and in dehumanizing ways only to turn around and want to use it positively for themselves - was strong enough for me.

and that's my choice, based on who i am and what i value. i don't have any particular attachment to any principles of language/ownership or anything, so this is easy for me. i don't know if that's the case for you or what it is specifically that makes you want to fight for this.

here's my math on that: if some people are genuinely hurt but a lot more people aren't hurt by a thing... and not doing the thing that hurts some people doesn't hurt the other larger group, i'll not do the thing. my goal is to cause the least harm to the world i live in.

honestly to me in my life in practice it's just not that deep, because what happened for me was someone told me it was harmful, i went ?! and looked it up and saw they were not alone, went ohhh and just... honored it. it isn't detrimental to me in any way to do that.

i mean this isn't just for white people? this is for all americans. some native americans said, "this hurts us, please stop doing it" and i said "ok" and that doesn't seem like a thing that should be limited to white or liberal. at least, i really hope not.

the reason i don't mind retiring a word from my personal lexicon is because the trade-off is that someone else will feel they matter more to me. it matters that if someone tells me, "hey this hurts me" that my response be, "then i'll stop doing it" rather than argue about it. yk?

yes, groups are not monoliths and individuals will not all feel the same way about a thing. some may not mind at all. but it's still worth it to me to care for the ones who do. that's what this is about. this isn't about editing the english language. this is about showing care.

yeah and in your case you should probably distrust it 2x as much since there are many people who won't want to disagree with you publicly because they look up to you and are afraid of upsetting you or other ppl who also respect you, so they may not say anything if they are upset.

in this case it's complex cause it's a little from column a and a little from column b. the appropriation bit is the classic "hang on, it's a bad thing when you use it to describe us it but you want to use it for your yuppie commune?!"
is there a particular threshold, for how many people genuinely feel disrespected, frustrated, tired of it, etc?

the logic is easy for me, to be honest, because my concern is primarily how my words land on the people who i am speaking to or who can 'hear' me. if they are even so much as like dried peas (on the scale of soap bubbles to boulders), i don't need them in my life anymore.

even that isn't across the board true, which makes "tribe" actually weirdly complex. many prefer "nation" because tribe has had *negative* connotations and has been used to dehumanize (making "tribal" equal to "savage" in usage, for both groups). so with all this...nah.

there's just so many fish in this sea, i don't feel the need to fight for the "right" to use anything that *genuinely* upsets people who have already had enough shit taken from them. this is such a small sacrifice for me and if it makes someone else more comfortable, what a deal!

since i'm not native american or african, i can't speak for them. i can say that i've read enough and listened to enough stuff from actually affected people that i retired it. i have access to so many other words that aren't objectionable, i rarely miss any of the ones that are.
boy you don't wanna know some of the words *i* learned in church

(but as a note, the word "asinine", regardless of any current problematic dictionary entries, is rooted in the concept of stubbornness, willfulness, obstinacy, etc, not the general concept of "intelligence")

in the case of intellect-based insults, you're correct. because our current ideas about intelligence are often rooted in racism and an inability to recognize our own ignorance, making judgements about general intelligence isn't wise.

you can choose to be clear. you can choose to be kind. you can have it all. or you could use an ableist slur because you are unwilling to take a few seconds to think further (or you are just spiteful and immature, whichever).

the etymology, not the meaning, is the factor at play here. you can use synonymous words that don't have a history of being used to harm others. the intelligence-based insults are a deeper issue because intelligence itself is a flawed concept but that's a bigger conversation.

to be honest, the alternative is to think about what you really mean. because we use those words to mean a lot of different things. unwise, ignorant, reckless, careless, obtuse, ridiculous, absurd, irresponsible, unpleasant, hurtful, unethical, etc etc. what do you really mean?

i'm actually disabled so i am aware of the options (or lack thereof; people really seem to think accommodation happens a lot more than it does).

if i absolutely cannot wear a whole mask, i'll wear a loose covering. if i can't wear a loose covering, i will not go where other people are. this isn't a case of the public trying to force a disabled person out of society. it's a case of me caring about other people's health.

my conditions sometimes make me feel like no matter how much i breathe, i'm not getting enough air. i also have phobias about having both my mouth and nose covered. it can be difficult for me to wear a mask. i will still never endanger public safety by going out without one.

that's pretty much it. i know it probably sounds a little weird (or a lot? i dunno), but if you're willing to try it, i'd like to know how it goes for you. and if you can, please rt or tag friends (who are ok with that sort of thing) for whom this may be relevant. thank you!

eat it only when you're feeling particularly bad; when i'm feeling pretty ok and i have it, it doesn't seem to do very much for me. it's when i'm having the worst dysautonomia it helps the most. if it helps, try to keep an eye on how long it helps you. it's variable for me.

make sure to eat it steadily and quickly. you don't want to eat it so fast that you get a really sharp ice cream headache or so fast you feel like you need a break, but you can't dawdle either. you need to keep applying it without pausing if possible.

i do add a little bit of chocolate sauce (trader joe's "midnight moo") for flavor, and if i add too much it messes with the efficacy, so if you do it, be cautious. you need a big bowl, like this is actually literally a whole meal kind of thing. like three big scoops kind of big.

the reason for the soymilk is because i don't drink regular milk so i just never have it on hand. i have no idea if it's an important part of the equation. i actually assume it's not because all this started with blizzards from dq so i don't think it's necessary, but

i pour soymilk on top and repeatedly spoon the milk over the ice cream so that the soymilk freezes. sometimes i break up the ice cream so there's more surface area and more milk freezes and i end up with a chunky mostly frozen ice cream soup. not blended like a milkshake though.

if you're willing: it has to be really dense/heavy ice cream, nothing "low calorie", most store brands won't do, but trader joe's brand does. it's what i use primarily. i've also used ben and jerry's. plain vanilla so far; i tried coffee and it has a different quality and result.

so...if you tolerate dairy and have similar issues as me, are you willing to try this very silly sounding experiment? for now it would just be a very simple "does it make you feel any better for a little while?" question. that's it for the moment.

it's such a dramatic short term improvement that before the ice cream, i can be gasping for air, have difficulty standing, not be able to think, etc ... and after i can *take a shower*. including washing my hair. i shit you not. hand to gourd, i tell the truth. ask my husband.

i have experimented with other ways of applying cold, and nothing works quite like very dense vanilla ice cream with soymilk. other flavors don't work the same, cheap fluffy ice cream doesn't work the same and ice cream w/o the added milk doesn't either.

i warned you, it sounds ridiculous. anyway, it's kinda like a really chunky, thick milkshake. i eat it pretty quickly, but *steadily*, staying just on the line of "brain freeze" without actually crossing it. it makes me feel significantly better for a short period of time.

i would like to see how many other people experience the same interesting thing as me. i'm also hoping to figure out if it has anything to do with cci. the basic idea: rapidly eating dense vanilla ice cream with soymilk is basically acting as an ice pack on my brain stem.

ok i'm about to ask for something that's going to sound really ridiculous, but hear me out. people with mecfs and/or cci (confirmed or not) who aren't getting much treatment right now, will you help me answer a question? it involves ice cream. yeah. i'll continue in thread...

lupine aphids are huge, too nasty for predators to eat, they poop a ton and the plants end up coated in a solid carpet of aphids, sticky poop and the resulting fungus that feeds on the poop. if lupine weren't a preferred food for so many of our native species of bumblebee...

oh no, i'm so sorry! that's called displaced aggression (can't bite the one you hate? bite the one you're with!) and that happens a lot, even to me, and it's so unexpected and it feels very much like betrayal tbh. :( even with a small bird it can hurt really bad. niko does it.
sometimes we are even bit very hard by our own parrots but usually that's our own dang fault.

even if you are a parrot person, you probably won't be able to predict an unknown parrot's reaction to any given stimuli because everything that has led up to that reaction is opaque to you. in other words, a lot of us have been bit very hard by a parrot, even if we are nice.

i am also afraid of larger birds. the very tiny birds don't scare me, but even medium birds with hookbills that are strangers to me are a bit scary. parrots are often, to strangers, unpredictable because their behavior is tuned specifically to their own flock...

crows, too! heck i bet there's a lot of other birds that can talk; birds don't have just one call they make, they are taught to 'speak' by their parents and flock. so whatever noises they are taught are the noises they make! whatever fits in their vocal range.

this is one of the interesting things about our assumptions: 1) that pointing out and facing inequalities *creates* division/unrest (rather have a boil than lance it?!) and 2) that there's ever a one-and-done. the civil rights wins of the 60s didn't fix it all. we keep fighting.

clarification: yes, very bad things continued to happen (including another devastating world war), but had america not been forced to acknowledge the mistreatment of marginalized people, we wouldn't have laid the necessary foundation for an eventually truly equal society.

the bell riots started us on a road of solving certain societal issues, and without it forcing america to pay attention to what was happening to marginalized people, we would have continued to ignore it and regardless of shit like wwiii, we would have stayed fucked.

after seeing that weird video of pots being taken from a kiln, i have gotten a bit teary eyed for my old life. i won't say i have regrets, i don't know where i'd be today if i'd made different choices, but this will always be what i loved most.
yes. the first bit (removing hot pots from a kiln) is entirely separate from the last bit (finished high fire stoneware pot), and the bit in the middle i think may be metalworking.

the cool thing is that it really does take a lot of effort to make intricate details show up on a pot glazed with tenmoku; the glaze when thick is deep black, but where thinner, the iron shows up red/brown, but less glossy. using it well takes a lot of skill.

that black stripe is the smoke permeating the clay after the red hot pot was placed into a container full of combustible materials. it burns inside the container, and eventually the fire uses all the oxygen and this affects the copper in the glaze, creating unpredictable results.
my pleasure. there's a lot to love about ceramic art, and some of it is flashy and exciting. here's an example of a raku fired pot by jean griffith:

the leaf design is a technique that's not easy to get right, so i don't want to diminish the skill and talent that the finished product represents, but it's a "normal" firing technique that's quite boring in practice.

the middle part i assume must be metalworking. the practice of removing freshly fired pots while still hot is part of raku. people doing it know the risks and try to mitigate danger, of course. the finished product at the end is fired in a high temp kiln.

i can only guess that the item shown being doused is metal. there is a technique that involves dunking freshly fired pots in a liquid, but it's not done like that and it will not result in what we see at the end of the video. the pot at the end has a less flashy technique

a second clarification: the technique shown at the very beginning where pots are taken from a kiln red hot is real (still dangerous but manageable). the middle, i could not tell you what is happening other than it can't be ceramic/glass and be safe at the same time.
yes, you are correct. it would break.
yes and no. the pot at the end exists, but the technique shown at the beginning is not how it was made.

this looks cool, but this video is false. the resulting pot shown in the video is stoneware glazed with what looks like tenmoku. the pot taken from the kiln at the beginning is not the same pot shown at the end. i don't like to be a killjoy but what's shown is very dangerous.

if any of the smaller birds are nesting and the crows haven't already noticed and don't already hang around nearby, maybe wait till nesting is over or feed far away from where they nest. crows will raid nests (but so will jays) so try not to call their attention to nests

holy. moly. ew, no, that's so terrible. giving them fatty foods is fine, but salty foods no. and i mean, ew bacon in the yard ew ew ew. they're good scavengers but terrible waste collectors. people think they can get rid of leftovers this way but nope. crows are super messy.

possums are the best! not so much raccoons, but oh well. if you just have two crows, i don't think you'll have to worry about over crowding for several years. i started with one young crow and now there's 5 after about 4 years or so? do you know if other birds nest close by?

i replied a little with general stuff that i do, in your tweet about it, but if you have any specific questions or want to tell me more about how many crows you have in your neighborhood or how you interact with them now, i'm all ears!

also i try never to feed when it's close to roosting time because either: everyone is told about it, which could invite trouble, or they ignore it to go roost and then the rats partake instead and i don't care to encourage them

and i never give them any food i wouldn't want to see in my birdbath right now i only have a small family that visits me, and if i am out there and they come up to me i say hi and ask if they want treats. if they don't leave, i give them a few nuts. that's pretty much it.

it could get out of hand, like any interaction with wildlife, but if you're cautious and intentional, that reduces the unintended consequences a little. i don't feed them regularly, and only when they come to my yard specifically. i only feed enough for 1-4 crows...

i hope that other researchers and medical professionals communicate that to both the research team and the media. for a lot of reasons, but one is that simply saying "you don't need to hoard" and "don't take too much" are not going to prevent people from doing those things.

so while supplementation in the case of deficiency is good in general, i'm not sure it's going to affect mortality rates if the cause of the deficiency is associated with an undiagnosed autoimmune disorder. i'll be interested to see what else they learn here.
people with autoimmune conditions are more likely to have vitamin d deficiencies and supplementation helps the side effects of the deficiency but it does not solve the underlying cause.

me, this morning to a tired maggie who wanted a nap: "whatcha doin'?" maggie: "good." (this is short for "good girl", not her telling me she is doing well) there's a lot of context unexplained behind the scenes here, but this is maggie replying to me, "i'm being a good girl".
oh my goodness that's lovely! i'm glad they did that too and i'm so sorry the rest of the world doesn't, that's a beautiful way to teach children to be.

also this is why we should take animal intelligence way more seriously. when they are physically capable of speaking our language at all, this is often how they sound. because they absolutely do understand the concepts. their bodies just aren't designed to verbalize like ours.

they demonstrate that the person speaking has a fundamental understanding of the goal ("dispose of these things") even if they don't have the exact words available. we often believe entities that don't use our language exactly correctly are less than, and that's a shame.

i know that these kinds of verbal "errors" are often seen in an uncharitable light (ableist stuff about mental deterioration), but they are an example of how dextrous and adaptable the brain really is. under immense strain, it can make these practical substitutions in real time.
me, not feeling well at all, asking husband to deal with a dirty glass that has a plastic straw in it: "could you put this in the goodbye?" ...well, brain, that does kind of cover it i guess.

the reason for the depletion is still our pollution, but the fluctuations in severity of depletion are due to the varying temperatures that lead to an environment where the reactions that cause ozone depletion can either flourish or abate. so, we get seasonal changes.

there isn't just one hole that remains static. the massive depletion that most people are familiar with is over the antarctic. this recent hole that formed was over the arctic and its formation and closure was related to the polar vortex.
the ozone hole that opened up and closed again is not false but it had nothing to do with people staying inside. it had to do with weather patterns.

to think it's my acne medication (and/or the combo of also taking grapefruit seed extract daily which is also newish)...explains why i've been viscerally resistant to the idea of ever stopping it. i've panicked over running out of them and felt very silly about it. not anymore.

i still have them, and the obsessive compulsive issues, but the frequency is in the basement, comparatively. and it's something i've dealt with my whole life, to my recollection. so these past few years of having less difficulty going the fuck to bed have been pretty noticeable.

i often realize i have a problem only after it's stopped being a problem and then becomes a problem again (lol) but i have frequently wondered what happened that reduced the number of nights i couldn't force myself to just take my pills and go the fuck to sleep "on time".

the reason i'm not taking my antibiotics is so i can take a test to see if i have small intestinal bacterial overgrowth. if i don't, i definitely have something going on in there because on the whole i've stopped having these problems with sleep since i started anti& probiotics.

i have a history of knowing instinctually that a medication i'm using is good for me for more reasons than the obvious one. best example: alprazolam is helpful in treatment of mast cell activation disorders, and i knew it was helping me physically, but i didn't know why.

ok there's no way that it's 100% a coincidence that i've been having way more difficulty trying to get to bed "at a reasonable hour" (fuck moralizing sleep) and having extra mental health struggles (these two things are related) after being off my daily antibiotics for acne.

the purpose of the cavities are to allow electrical and plumbing conduits and to insulate the inside of the house from heat, cold and moisture. it works pretty well, and if you're kind to your house and keep it well maintained, there no problems. :)

for me, the cavities in the wall are not concerning, because i know how they're built and generally what goes inside them. i also know that the inside of the house is pretty well sealed up. unless, you know, you destroy your own wall.

i'm so worn down. i've been having migraines for a solid week+. i can't play stardew to escape, i even hurt in my sleep, and i dunno how to readjust yet. i am going to get there, but it's pretty fucking hilarious i thought "no big deal, i've been doing this forever" at first.

i have underestimated, or forgotten, or both, the amount of spoons, health and strife that cleaners have saved me over the years. with a husband w/adhd, it's solely up to me to be the driver of clean because he simply will not and i can't change that. the spoon deficit is huge.

and no one can come to help me with the housecleaning tasks that will break me if i do them, so i have done them sometimes, and broke me. i also can't give up on braining about food and ask for takeout. so i have to use the brain spoons to plan all our meals. it's so many spoons.

and how his schedule would change, he gets up at a different time etc. i no longer have a big block of time *completely* to myself from 9-6. even now that he has set up a desk in the shop, he still comes in for lunch and stuff. and if i am sleeping he comes and wakes me up, w/

i didn't think i'd need to make adjustments to staying at home all the time because that's already how i live all the time and have for years so nothing would be different, but of course that's incorrect. i didn't account for the changes that come with husband being home 24/7...

also antiseptic: citric acid. if you have veggie spray, that'll do. i have a bathroom cleaner with citric acid active ingredient and i use that to soak the cage and then hose it off in the shower. it tears through poop like it's nothing, washes off completely and isn't stinky.

acetic acid is an antiseptic at 1% solution and vinegar is at minimum 4% acetic acid, it's plenty good enough for cleaning cages. i don't really recommend cleaning porous wood perches with anything, they should be tossed. you could boil them i guess but i don't play with that.

if a colony is established but the queen dies, her daughters may try in vain to continue the colony by laying eggs themselves. but without the extra set of genetic material, they can only lay male eggs. male bumblebees leave the nest forever upon maturation, so aren't any help.

male bumblebees only exist to provide genetic material for the new queens, so the queen only lays male eggs at the end of the season when she allows new queens. in late fall/early winter all the bumblebees but new queens are dead. in spring, there are only queens and daughters.

there's a lot to love about homeschool. also a lot of pitfalls. so i kinda had a mixed experience but overall for me it was the best option. i started community college at 13, which was also amazing because they treat everyone like adults, which... worked out a lot better, haha.
it's not the same and it's all for the best anyway as i do not have the spoons for that.

and she was joking a lot of the times, but those moments were often useful to me because it made me more curious about stuff. teaching isn't just infodumping. it's not supposed to be tedious. we're not supposed to dread it. i still love learning, and i wish that for everyone.

i was only in public school for a few years. i was miserable, bullied and failing. being able to learn in a way that *i* loved, that worked for me, made me eager to learn more. my mom would take us on errands and be like, 'look! a bird nest in that tree! ok, school's done!'

to be honest, one of my tiny quiet secret regrets about not having kids is not being able to teach them how cool learning stuff is, show them the joy of discovering things and figuring things out and protecting them from getting that crushed by school. let kids learn joyfully.

i'm just so sad that so many schools are trying to force school schedules at home. sitting, glued to the computer for 8 hours? yanked from subject to subject every hour? that's exhausted office worker stuff. they're kids, ffs. parents should be allowed to do better if they can.

(to be honest, kids should start the day playing, running around, etc, learn some stuff, have another run around break, learn some more, then run around again. physical movement really helps memory retention. but that wasn't exactly the point of me saying go outside and play.)

past that, they're not going to actually remember any of the stuff you try to teach them. if you want them to actually learn learn in a way they remember for a long time, unlock the brain, stuff in reasonable amounts of info and then *send them outside to play.*

but if you only have a few kids, or even just one, you can figure out their thing and cater to it. it's amazing how much learning you can cram in there once you have a receptive brain. in fact, if you're doing it right, you can only do it for a couple of hours.

we use brute force repetition to teach classrooms right now because we can't figure out each individual child's thing and cater to all the things at once. many things are mutually exclusive. so we hammer at it over time until it reluctantly stays in just long enough to test.

i was homeschooled for many years. it just so happened that i responded very well to just being given a lot of books. i tore through everything and because reading was my jam, i learned super fast. if you find your kid's jam, they'll learn quickly too.

i'm super shocked by how many of the replies are from parents whose kids are being given such overly structured schoolwork while they are at home. while at home, you have an opportunity to figure out how your kids learn and do concentrated learning! great thread btw.

asparagus is a great one to find a patch for now if you're patient - you'll not get any for three years but after that they'll produce bigger and better every year from then on. plant them next to where you'll plant tomatoes at some point and in the meantime grow dill there.

greens are only good if you want to eat them. you can plant spinach now, collards, mustard greens, peas. consider peas for their greens too, you can eat young pea shoots and the little tendrils the older plants grow in addition to the peas themselves...

sage advice, i see what you did there! i'm happy to help anytime i have the spoons, it's something i love. and if you don't actually want to eat lettuce, consider root veg like carrots, turnips, beets, radishes. you can plant radishes right now if you want...

if you have room for 5, plant 2 on day one, 2 more the next week and 1 more the week after. use plenty of seeds since lettuce seeds are iffy. if it's a head lettuce, trim extras. leafy ones, i think you can let em all grow. you can grow lettuce indoors too, with a grow light!

a lot of strongly scented herbs are slight deterrents to pests and inviting to beneficial bugs, so consider some flavorings plant lettuce in stages all throughout the season so you don't get overwhelmed with a big harvest all at once...

smaller critters are more difficult to deal with but if you use plastic mulch around the lettuce it's harder for slugs to hide. white plastic mulch helps keep the soil cooler. if you can, plant a nasturtium trap a few feet away to lure the aphids away from the lettuce...
lettuces do well in large containers and i recommend containing them with chicken wire or mesh to keep them from being delicious snacks to big critters...

yeah! buy seeds instead of starts if you're wanting to keep growing and eating all summer/fall. lettuces prefer cooler temps, so find a morning sun/dappled afternoon shade spot if you have one. if not, you can make a little shade cover to help in the summer...

the other thing that makes this situation unique is that all of us can do something about it and our actions can have a direct positive impact and save lives. we are not completely helpless and at the mercy of an uncaring cheeto. we can do this. it's not easy, but it's possible.

only if that's what you were going to do anyway. i'm probably going to take a bit of a semi scheduled break soon to do household stuff, but tbh i can't really look away if there's anything that can help, y'know?

and not only is it important, it's time sensitive and it matters very much that the correct information is disseminated as quickly as possible. i don't get to be quite as distracted or distracting as usual. i wish it weren't this way. i'll try to do some distracteys soon.

i know i'm not really posting my usual parrots, bees, plants, silliness tweets and i'm not following my usual "combat bad news with bird photos and distractions" strategy. i know that all of this is anxiety inducing. but where i am, literally and figuratively, this is important.

we absolutely need a "main street bailout" - restaurants, service industry, construction, entertainment, everything that would be empty whether due to illness or quarantine needs this assistance. this is necessary. if we can do it for banks, we can do it for everyone else.

the choice is between: financial hardships and a broken healthcare system that results in many tragically unnecessary deaths or financial hardships and a functioning healthcare system that can adequately treat the severely ill and reduce unnecessary deaths

i think a lot of people do not understand that the economic impact of the pandemic is unavoidable. the choice is not between avoiding financial hardships or avoiding unnecessary deaths. the financial hardships will happen whether we isolate now or let everyone get sick now.
hahaha, you hit the most important supplies! me, i made husband make sure i had a lot of dr. pepper.

we've got tons of preppers here too, but i think they might be more focused on the non perishables. i think if you are able to avoid costco or the like it will be easier to find stuff. preppers love costco.

again, many of us are trying very hard to get help for everyone - businesses are going under, my neighbors are suffering. but this hardship would *still happen* if everyone got sick at once, so if we can save any lives, we should try. we will keep trying to get help for all.

i know this is really hard. many of us are lobbying to get financial relief for the many many people financially affected. the truth is, the bigger picture is that the financial hardship is inevitable even without these measures, but with these measures fewer people will die.

it's still likely that all controlled stuff like pain medication, stimulants, benzodiazepines, sleep aids, etc will not be allowed an early refill as it's not necessarily insurance that's the obstacle there. but good info for non scheduled stuff! thank you.

huge gratitude to the northshore school district who jumped on closing almost right away. because they closed before all their staff became ill, they can spend time identifying and meeting the kids' needs for distance learning. food delivery, disability accommodations, etc.

and the more we expose the staff of those schools to the virus, the lower the chance they'll be able to return to helping those kids. put on your own oxygen mask first, etc. the people running the programs right now aren't expendable. don't wait till they're already dying to act.

delaying the closure of schools (and it's only a delay, how long you think those adult staff, many elderly, are going to last?) may seem sensitive to those with needs but they'll suffer more & longer if we don't deal with it now before we are overwhelmed. we have a short window.

no, we don't really have a plan and we need to get the resources. but we will be stopped on a dime *whether we are ready or not* as the kids are carriers. i get that it's complicated but keeping the schools open will hinder our attempts to flatten the curve.

as someone who gets migraine related aphasia, it bothers me a lot when people insist that saying the wrong word must mean dementia. i haven't forgotten my wedding anniversary, my brain just made my mouth say "october" instead of "may". it's shitty to dunk on people for this.

sometimes it's not even necessarily a conscious choice, as this is how he's dealt with it his entire life and his brain has to make the replacements very quickly. it's not always going to come up with the perfect replacement - thursday is not tuesday. yeah, we know. so does he.

for those that don't understand why a stutter would result in these verbal weirdnessess: it's because of how he works around the stutter. when he comes up on a word or phrase he realizes he can't say, he chooses a new word, phrase or tactic altogether.

yes, i'm talking about his stutter. he has chosen to claim he had one, past tense, but in reality, he still has it and works around it by choosing other words mid sentence when he realizes he can't say what he wants to say. or he just aborts/pivots away.

he has a stutter and he works around it by choosing other words mid-sentence when he realizes he can't say the word, or he aborts the attempt to say it entirely. he claims he had a stutter and won't acknowledge that his "cure" is actually a work around.

and he refuses to acknowledge that he still has a stutter but works around it by choosing other words mid-sentence. he claims he had a stutter, past tense. it's not true, and it sucks he won't own up to it and how it affects his speech.

i've read that people dealing directly with him report he has difficulty with the words, but not the concepts. i'm very weary of the bashing based on inability to force your face hole to make the correct mouth noises. if you don't like him, choose something else to pick on.

both to himself and to the rest of us. a lot of us have neurological conditions that can present with similar symptoms. we're not "losing [our] minds" and we don't have dementia. in my case, i have aphasia. i know what i want to say but i can't say it.

it's a serious disservice that biden has so internalized all the ableism that he won't be more open about the reasons he sometimes doesn't say words or phrases, or says random words instead, or appears to lose his train of thought and switches tactics mid sentence, jumbling it.

by killing bacteria only. this does nothing to your immune system but lighten its load a little bit. which is why it helps me in particular i think, activating my immune system is very bad so if i can avoid it, i do.

also adding, all the usual warnings about drug interactions, not taking my word as gold, etc. i have been using this for years and find the sprays in particular are pretty dramatically helpful in my own experience, but i don't evangelize, because there's not a lot of good data.

(grapefruit seed extract is pretty powerful and like regular antibiotics it seems to be able to wipe out your gut bacteria so don't overdo it. the throat spray has zinc so follow directions exactly, overdoing that can hurt.)

i do the nasal spray preventively when i go out, throat spray at night if i am suspicious, pills as needed but cautious with them as they also seem to kill gut bacteria if i'm too fast and loose with them and that hurts

the nasal spray kills gems in the mucus where it's trying to incubate, same for the throat spray but the latter also has zinc. i have actually stomped some bacterial infections i'd normally need meds for (i used to get a ton, sadly i know the signs) by taking the gse pills.

it's hard to say exactly how much, but i have been able to expose myself to a lot of scary shit (like multi day conventions) without waking the hulk and when i make husband use them, it often cuts down the amount and length of sickness and he doesn't pass it on to me.

confidential to my fellow spoonies with angry immune systems that keep trying to kill us or squashed flat ones that can't do much: i have found that nutribiotic's line of nasal spray, throat spray and pills with grapefruit seed extract help me out somewhat.
